column3: On her way home she again glanced up at the Wilcoxes' flat, and took the rather matronly step of speaking about the matter to Helen.

column2: Helen, you must tell me whether this thing worries you.
column3: Helen, you must tell me whether this thing worries you.

column2: If what? said Helen, who was washing her hands for lunch.
column3: If what? said Helen, who was washing her hands for lunch.

column2: The W.'s coming.
column3: The w's coming.

column2: No, of course not.
column3: No, of course not.

column2: Really?
column3: Really?

column2: Really. Then she admitted that she was a little worried on Mrs. Wilcox's account; she implied that Mrs. Wilcox might reach backward into deep feelings, and be pained by things that never touched the other members of that clan.
column3: Really. Then she admitted that she was a little worried on mrs Wilcox's account; she implied that mrs Wilcox might reach backward into deep feelings, and be pained by things that never touched the other members of that clan.

column2: I shan't mind if Paul points at our house and says, 'There lives the girl who tried to catch me.' But she might.
column3: I shan't mind if Paul points at our house and says, 'There lives the girl who tried to catch me.' But she might.

column2: If even that worries you, we could arrange something.	If even that worries you, we could arrange something.
column3: true

column2: There's no reason we should be near people who displease us or whom we displease, thanks to our money.
column3: There's no reason we should be near people who displease us or whom we displease, thanks to our money.

column2: We might even go away for a little."
column3: We might even go away for a little."

column2: Well, I am going away.	Well, I am going away.
column3: true

column2: Frieda's just asked me to Stettin, and I shan't be back till after the New Year.
column3: Frieda's just asked me to Stettin, and I shan't be back till after the New Year.

column2: Will that do?
column3: Will that do?

column2: Or must I fly the country altogether?
column3: Or must I fly the country altogether?

column2: Really, Meg, what has come over you to make such a fuss?"
column3: Really, Meg, what has come over you to make such a fuss?"

column2: Oh, I'm getting an old maid, I suppose.	Oh, I'm getting an old maid, I suppose.
column3: false

column2: I thought I minded nothing, but really I--I should be bored if you fell in love with the same man twice and"--she cleared her throat--"you did go red, you know, when Aunt Juley attacked you this morning.
column3: I thought I minded nothing, but really I-I should be bored if you fell in love with the same man twice and"--she cleared her throat-"you did go red, you know, when Aunt Juley attacked you this morning.

column2: I shouldn't have referred to it otherwise."
column3: I shouldn't have referred to it otherwise."

column2: But Helen's laugh rang true, as she raised a soapy hand to heaven and swore that never, nowhere and nohow, would she again fall in love with any of the Wilcox family, down to its remotest collaterals.
column3: But Helen's laugh rang true, as she raised a soapy hand to heaven and swore that never, nowhere and nohow, would she again fall in love with any of the Wilcox family, down to its remotest collaterals.
